awd_titl_txt: GCR: Understanding Virus Evolution Through Deep Raman Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
This Growing Convergence Research project aims at revolutionizing how circulating epidemic and pandemic influenza virus strains are surveilled and characterized.  The project brings together virologists who perform controlled mutations of the virus, nanoscience engineers who create platforms for virus enrichment, materials scientists and optical spectroscopists who develop effective 2D material Raman signal enhancement platforms, and data scientists who analyze data with machine learning methods to achieve virus identification and prediction of potential emergence of new antigenic variants.  The goal of the research team is to develop a convergent device platform that can rapidly capture, sense, and identify viruses and predict new antigenic strains against which the human population has limited or no immunity.

The project pursues a solution to a grand challenge in the surveillance and characterization of circulating epidemic and pandemic influenza virus strains by addressing deep scientific questions in enhanced Raman spectroscopy for virus detection and evolution prediction. The proposed platform is based on controlled virology experiments that propagate by culture and mutate viruses for specific research tasks, a novel virus enrichment platform for effectively capturing viruses without labels, biosensing of virus surface proteins with enhanced signal through a novel 2D/metal enhanced Raman spectroscopy technique, and rapid and sensitive virus identification and evolution prediction through machine learning analysis of enhanced Raman data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
We have several achievments in this project that include the development of a novel techniques to rapidly and precisely identify influenza and corona viruses. An integrated device platform to efficiently enrich and capture viruses through vertically aligned CNT and optimal Raman enhancement substrates for viruses. 

The project brings together four fields—molecular epidemiology, nanoscience, spectroscopy and data science. These independent fields, through convergence in this project, will build new avenues to resolve critical problems that are challenging to tackle using only the knowledge within each individual field. Using materials science, spectroscopy and data science to creatively and effectively solve a long-term question in epidemiology, virus identification and detection of mutated variants. New technologies of microbe detection and prediction will also be developed as a result of the convergent effort, which will enable real-time surveillance of circulating strains and monitoring of epidemics and potential epidemics. The project lead to new platforms for identifying epidemic strains of viruses and selection of strains for vaccine development, and inspire studies on other infectious diseases, as well as convergent research of bio-materials-physics-data fields to benefit public health. spectra of viruses will also be built, which will have long-lasting value for academia, health organizations, hospitals, pharmaceutical industries, etc. 

New platform to detect coronavirus: In our project, we have collected Raman spectra of human influenza strains and chicken coronavirus strains and used machine learning to achieve very high accuracy in identifying viruses. We have also demonstrated high-accuracy classification of RBDs from different coronaviruses including SARS-CoV-2. We believe our technology can provide a fast, label-free, and portable platform for rapidly detecting and identifying human coronavirus strains, with great impact in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic.

Application of machine learning-Raman spectroscopy integrated technique on other biosensing domains: We have developed a unique tool that integrates machine learning with Raman spectroscopy for sensitively detecting biomolecules and interpreting the signatures. We have used this integrated technique for a number of other biosensing scenarios than virus detection, including DNA sequencing and neural diseases. This unique tool will continue to benefit a variety of biomedical and health areas.


Last Modified: 02/06/2025
Modified by: Mauricio Terrones

  • The Carbon nanotube-gold platform is able to detect proteins that are part of the SARs-CoV-2 virus. This protocol can also be used for any protein or virus.
    Mauricio Terrones

    Identification of proteins in viruses
  • This project will lead to platforms for identifying epidemic strains of viruses and selection of strains for vaccine development. A world-wide data bank for Raman spectra of viruses could also be built. The Raman spectra repository built will serve as a valuable reference for researchers worldwide.

    Vision of the Project
  • We developed deep learning algorithms that are interpretable and give signatures that are important for differentiating virus types, subtypes, strains and antigenic variants.

    Machine Learning research to accurately identify viruses
